summary: This is an email from defense attorney Laura Menninger to Judge Nathan and other parties, requesting an adjournment of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial and seeking to redact the names and case numbers of her other clients from the motion letter, citing attorney-client confidentiality rules.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell who sends a letter motion requesting an adjournment of the trial and seeks redaction of other clients' information.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: Judge Nathan is the recipient of the email and the letter motion regarding the adjournment request in the case US v. Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the adjournment request in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Stemhenn
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the adjournment request in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the adjournment request in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case US v. Maxwell, whose trial adjournment is being requested by her counsel.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is acting as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, filing motions on her behalf.
Attorney Menninger is communicating with Judge Nathan regarding court procedures and motions in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: The Court issued an order (Dkt. 221) referenced in the email, likely related to filing procedures for the adjournment motion.

events.title: Request for Trial Adjournment
events.description: Defense counsel files a letter motion requesting a 120 or 180-day adjournment of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial.

keyFacts: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell requested an adjournment of her trial by 120 or 180 days.
The defense cited attorney-client confidentiality rules (Rule of Professional Conduct 1.6) to request redaction of other clients' names and case numbers from the public motion.
The email indicates the legal team's strategy to protect confidential client information even when it might be publicly available from other sources.
The correspondence shows ongoing pre-trial procedural motions in the high-profile case US v. Maxwell.
